Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Hyphenated Surface Plasmon Resonance Techniques for Enhanced Biomolecular Interaction Studies and Biomarker Detections
Award.AbstractNarration:
Professor Feimeng Zhou of California State L A University is supported by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging (CMI) Program in the Division of Chemistry to interface surface plasmon resonance (SPR) with various analytical and separation techniques and use the hyphenated analytical tools to study molecular binding events and to identify biomarkers of relevance to neurological disorders. Three related projects are proposed. Electrochemical flow-injection SPR will be used to determine ligand-receptor binding; imaging SPR will be used for high-throughput screening of potential inhibitors of beta-secretase, which is relevant to the pathology of Alzheimer's disease; and label-free SPR will be combined with size-exclusion chromatography for the separation and detection of Alzheimer's disease-related peptides and protein fragments.

If successful, the proposed research will lead to the development of new hyphenated analytical tools which may positively impact the diagnosis and therapy of Alzheimer's disease and other neurological disorders. Undergraduate students in a minority serving institution will be trained in analytical instrumentation, device fabrication, surface chemistry, biosensor, and neurochemistry, and will be motivated to pursue advanced studies in chemistry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research Project: From 2011 to 2014, the NSF grant 1112105 entitled “Hyphenated Surface Plasmon Resonance Techniques for Enhanced Biomolecular Interaction Studies and Biomarker Detections” was awarded to Dr. Feimeng Zhou at California State University, Los Angeles (CSULA). The grant was approved for no-cost extensions until August 2016. During this five-year period, the project involved twelve students (six undergraduate students, five M. S. graduate students and one high school student) and four part-time research technicians. The PI and these researchers collectively published 16 research articles in high-quality, high-impact journals in the following three areas: (1) New applications of surface plasmon resonance (SPR), with emphasis placed on high-throughput biochemical analysis; (2) Development of Sample Introduction Systems for Various Analytical Techniques; (3) Effective coupling with new analytical techniques to study various chemical and biochemical problems related to neurological disorders; and (4) Tandem use of analytical instruments and surface characterization techniques for other projects (e.g. solar cells and chemically modified electrodes).  

Intellectual Merit: The advantages of SPR for studying biomolecular interactions and biomarker detection include high sensitivity, low sample consumption, collection of kinetic and thermodynamic information in real time, and the obviation of labeling molecules for detection. Combination of SPR with other analytical techniques facilitated the significant expansion of SPR applications and provided new insight into factors and processes that are related to the etiology of neurological disorders. The various projects are transformative and ambitious and address both fundamental and applied problems in surface chemistry, analytical instrumentation, and neurochemistry. These projects effectively capitalize on the advantages of SPR and its combination with various analytical techniques in addressing some long-standing problems of Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s diseases. As the research projects are seamlessly integrated with curriculum development, community outreach, infrastructure building at CSULA and collaborative research projects with other groups on and off campus, they have contributed to science/engineering education and research.    

Broader Impacts: The project ensured the continuation of the PI’s productive research with undergraduate and master’s level graduate students and other research personnel in the past five years. Support for the proposed research effort has allowed the PI to continue his endeavor in recruiting and training undergraduate students in areas of analytical instrumentation, device fabrication, chemical and biological sensing, surface chemistry, neurochemistry, and studies of cellular processes. The project has broader impacts on various aspects, including the development of new tools for molecular and biomolecular interaction studies and detection, transfer of knowledge, and motivation of undergraduate students, particularly those from underrepresented minority groups, to pursue advanced degrees in the STEM fields and to become productive members of the workforce in our country.
